column4: My Ubuntu Software Center won't launch. It opens and closes immediately..
I tried apt-get update and upgrade and reinstall of software-center
Are you using an encrypted home directory?
I don't know, even what that means :)
Try "sudo dpkg-reconfigure software-center --force "
I did it but still no go. I will post new log
From what I see, it looks to be related to Ubuntu One' single-sign-on service. Do you have an Ubuntu One account configured ?
Hmmm... I wonder if that's the issue? I've seen sillier where software assumes it should have an account and fails otherwise. Let me dig a bit.
OK. Thank you for helping
Just to confirm. You're running software center as a regular user, not trying to start it using sudo/gksudo ?
I simply typed "software-center" in the terminal
Thanks. Just trying to narrow down the scope
should we pick this up another time
I'm looking at the code in ubuntu-sso-client-gtk - it's Python - and it uses a logger. That infers we should be able to get the process to log what it's up to and maybe give us a clue.
I'm all ears :o
It's way over my head but I'll be able to follow your instructions
I might not have any yet! The code is worse than spaghetti!
Maybe that is the problem haha
I think I've almost pinned down the log-file location :p
:D
That package is a 'recommends' of ubuntu-sso-client, and it actually contains the code that is missing.

OK, the logs go to "~/.cache/sso/" . To enable DEBUG level for the SSO component it needs "U1_DEBUG=1" in the environment. Simply setting that for software-center doesn't help, so I need to figure out how to set it when SSO is started by the DBus service
No idea what you just said but I like it so far.....
:p

Use 2 terminal sessions: In the first run this and leave it running: "U1_DEBUG=True python /usr/lib/ubuntu-sso-client/ubuntu-sso-login". In the other terminal, run software-center. After it crashes, check the end of ~/.cache/sso/sso-client.log for entries that include "DEBUG" rather than just "INFO"
maks@ubuntu:~$ U1_DEBUG=True python /usr/lib/ubuntu-sso-client/ubuntu-sso-login
Nice catch :)
what release of ubuntu are you using?
check with "lsb_release -a"
That suggests you've have incomplete packages
This mat fix it: "sudo apt-get --reinstall install ubuntu-sso-client"
done, now what
Yes... I suspect though, you'll need to also do "sudo apt-get --reinstall install ubuntu-sso-client-gtk"
yea
Have you alternated any settings within 'apt' to stop it installing recommended packages?
OK, give it a go with software-center now
http://pastebin.com/d3nvqnWs and http://pastebin.com/hRQSgaaL
That didn't appear to help did it!?
no :o
Well, you have the files, but for some reason Python isn't finding the ubuntu_sso
aha!
What did you try to do? install a different python version?
I don't remember what I was trying to install, but it required some python stuff, and I dont remember where google took me, or to what commands. I installed python. That is all I remember. :(
what does "python --version" report?
OK, that's good. and bad... because it ought to be finding the SSO python package!
This *feels* like the wrong python interpreter version is being used by default and that version doesn't have the SSO files in its dist-packages/ directory
hm, so maybe I should somehow uninstall all pythons?
What does this tell you? " dpkg-query -l python{2,3}* | grep '^ii'  "
No, you shouldn't! Ubuntu relies on Python these days for core services
You missed out a single-quote, or included the double-quotes which I provide just to separate the commands from my commentary. Press Ctrl+C to break out and try again
That looks correct too
outta ideas?
I'm trying to figure out what you managed to do to python. Maybe we can avoid needing to know by doing "sudo dpkg-reconfigure python2.7"
You may also need to do "sudo dpkg-reconfigure python2.7-minimal"
not outputting something is a sign of success for most *nix command line tools
py "thong" ?!?! :D
OK, try the "U1_DEBUG=True python /usr/lib/ubuntu-sso-client/ubuntu-sso-login" again
same error?
grrrr! We need a Python packaging expert
I know what it's not doing but not how to correct it
If you knew what you did to it with Python yesterday...
let me look
Arghhh!!!!!!!!!
So you installed the upstream package! I bet it's in /usr/local/bin/ and is being picked up instead of the Ubuntu installation!!!
You deserve to wear that thong!! LOL ... OK ... check if I'm correct: "ls -l /usr/local/bin/python*"
You installed Python from a source package provided by the Python project, rather than letting the already-installed Ubuntu package do its thing
Anything that is installed that isn't part of the distro usually will install to /usr/local/*
So, we found your problem. Now you need to uninstall that. I'm guessing you extracted that python tar.gz file to directory, is that correct?
If so, change to the directory where you extracted the file (or else re-extract the file now) ... and then in it's directory try "sudo make uninstall"
change into that Python-2.7.3/ directory first
the one in Downloads/ yes
then try doing "sudo make uninstall" ... that ought to remove all the files it installed into your system in /usr/local/*
it says maks@ubuntu:~/Downloads/Python-2.7.3$ sudo make uninstall
Try this: " ./configure && su -c 'make uninstall'  "
OK ... you must have done it as root so do this  "sudo ./configure && sudo -make uninstall  "
you get my link ?
You there?
is a genius, guys.

The 'default' java launched without a path given is set by the update_alternatives system. To launch a particular version of the Java interpreter, you give its path explictly: e.g. "/usr/lib/jvm/java-1.6.0-openjdk-amd64/bin/java" - you can find all the installed Java version in "/usr/lib/jvm/"
thanks. If I install sun java it will not try to replace the openjdk and give me similar problem as when I installed the python? :)
It won't replace, no, but it may try to make itself the default in the update-alternatives system. That can be changed, though, after the event
thanks !

Windows can usually shrink its own partition from Disk Management. Once that is done, boot from an Ubuntu liveCD, and use gparted to move the start of the Ubuntu partition so that the size of the Ubuntu allocation increases as it takes up the free space.
I'm using WUBI, does that make like a 'virtual' partition or something, rather than a real one?
no, in your case there's simply a file in the Windows NTFS file system
and vivid : then I should probably uninstall this and reinstall, huh?
see https://help.ubuntu.com/community/ResizeandDuplicateWubiDisk
The link you put is to resize the wubi installation.. should I just uninstall and do real install with real partition isntead? Vivid said virtual drive is slower
If you want to keep on with Ubuntu then that would be best.
any way to save all my stuff so that it'll have my files and programs?

It is possible to simply copy the contents of the wubi virtual drive into a hard-drive partition, and set-up the boot-loader from there, but all in all, that would be too complicated for you I think :)
haha, ok, thanks :0
Inside a virtual machine! Not on a real disk
